greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Least number k >= 0 such that (n!+k)/(n+k) is prime.
comment: a(n) <= n!-2n for all n. See A242567.
Since 2 is prime, we see that (n!+k)/(n+k) = 2 when k = n!-2n, which is an integer. Thus, a(n) will always be nonzero. However, it is uncertain whether there are smaller k-values besides n!-2n.
link: Hiroaki Yamanouchi, Table of n, a(n) for n = 3..60
results.author: _Derek Orr_, May 17 2014
